answer_html: Thus, there is overdamping for \(\gamma > 6\) and underdamping for \(\gamma < 6\) (and therefore critical damping if \(\gamma=6\)).
answer_latex:
Thus, there is overdamping for $\gamma > 6$ and underdamping for

hints_html: What are the roots of the characteristic equation as a function of \(\gamma\).
hints_latex:
What are the roots of the characteristic equation as a function of
$\gamma$.
hints_raw: What are the roots of the characteristic equation as a function of <math>\gamma</math>.
question: 4 (a)
sols_html:
Given the equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}2u'' + 2 \gamma u' + 18 u = 0,\end{aligned}\]

we can obtain the characteristic equation by substituting a solution

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}u(t)=\exp(rt)\end{aligned}\]

and looking at the resulting polynomial. Doing this we get

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}2r^2 + 2 \gamma r + 18 = 0\end{aligned}\]

which has roots

\[\begin{aligned} r &= \frac{-2\gamma \pm \sqrt{4 \gamma^2 - 4(2)(18)}}{4} \\ &= -\frac{\gamma}{2} \pm \frac{\sqrt{\gamma^2 - 36}}{2} \\ &= \frac12\left(-\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^2-6^2}\right)\end{aligned}\]

.

Now we study the behaviour of the roots of the equation. Note that \(\gamma > 0\) is necessary for physical damping.

  • When \(\gamma^2 - 36 < 0\), there are complex roots to the system, and there are oscillations. Thus the system is underdamped.

  • When \(\gamma^2 - 36 > 0\), the square root always yields a real value. Since \(\sqrt{\gamma^2 - 36} < \gamma\) (assuming \(\gamma>0\)), it follows that both roots are negative (so the amplitude decays) and real (so there are no oscillations). Thus, the system is overdamped.

Thus, there is overdamping for \(\gamma > 6\) and underdamping for \(\gamma < 6\) (and therefore critical damping if \(\gamma=6\)).
sols_latex:
Given the equation

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}2u'' + 2 \gamma u' + 18 u = 0,
\end{align*}

we can obtain the characteristic equation by substituting a solution

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}u(t)=\exp(rt)
\end{align*}

and looking at the resulting polynomial. Doing this we get

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}2r^2 + 2 \gamma r + 18 = 0
\end{align*}

which has roots

\begin{align*}
r &= \frac{-2\gamma \pm \sqrt{4 \gamma^2 - 4(2)(18)}}{4} \\
&= -\frac{\gamma}{2} \pm \frac{\sqrt{\gamma^2 - 36}}{2} \\
&= \frac12\left(-\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^2-6^2}\right)
\end{align*}.

Now we study the behaviour of the roots of the equation. Note that
$\gamma > 0$ is necessary for physical damping.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  When $\gamma^2 - 36 < 0$, there are complex roots to the system, and
  there are oscillations. Thus the system is \emph{underdamped}.
\item
  When $\gamma^2 - 36 > 0$, the square root always yields a real value.
  Since $\sqrt{\gamma^2 - 36} < \gamma$ (assuming $\gamma>0$), it
  follows that both roots are negative (so the amplitude decays) and
  real (so there are no oscillations). Thus, the system is
  \emph{overdamped}.
\end{itemize}

Thus, there is overdamping for $\gamma > 6$ and underdamping for
$\gamma < 6$ (and therefore critical damping if $\gamma=6$).
sols_raw:
Given the equation

:<math>
\displaystyle{}2u'' + 2 \gamma u' + 18 u = 0,
</math>

we can obtain the characteristic equation by substituting a solution

:<math>
\displaystyle{}u(t)=\exp(rt)
</math>

and looking at the resulting polynomial.  Doing this we get

:<math>
\displaystyle{}2r^2 + 2 \gamma r + 18 = 0
</math>

which has roots

:<math>
\begin{align}
r &= \frac{-2\gamma \pm \sqrt{4 \gamma^2 - 4(2)(18)}}{4} \\
&= -\frac{\gamma}{2} \pm \frac{\sqrt{\gamma^2 - 36}}{2} \\
&= \frac12\left(-\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^2-6^2}\right)
\end{align}
</math>.

Now we study the behaviour of the roots of the equation. Note that <math>\gamma > 0</math> is necessary for physical damping.

* When <math>\gamma^2 - 36 < 0</math>, there are complex roots to the system, and there are oscillations. Thus the system is ''underdamped''.
* When <math>\gamma^2 - 36 > 0</math>, the square root always yields a real value. Since <math>\sqrt{\gamma^2 - 36} < \gamma</math> (assuming <math>\gamma>0</math>), it follows that both roots are negative (so the amplitude decays) and real (so there are no oscillations). Thus, the system is ''overdamped''.

Thus, there is overdamping for <math>\gamma > 6</math> and underdamping for <math>\gamma < 6 </math> (and therefore critical damping if <math>\gamma=6</math>).
statement_html:
Suppose the motion of a spring-mass system is described by the following differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} 2u'' + 2\gamma u' + 18u = 0, \quad u(0) = 1,\quad u'(0) = -\frac{11}2\end{aligned}\]

(a) Find all values of the parameter \(\gamma\) for which the system is overdamped or critically damped (that is the mass cannot pass its equilibrium position more than once, so there are no oscillatory solutions).
statement_latex:
Suppose the motion of a spring-mass system is described by the following
differential equation

\begin{align*}
2u'' + 2\gamma u' + 18u = 0, \quad u(0) = 1,\quad u'(0) = -\frac{11}2
\end{align*}

\textbf{(a)} Find all values of the parameter $\gamma$ for which the
system is overdamped or critically damped (that is the mass cannot pass
its equilibrium position more than once, so there are no oscillatory
solutions).
statement_raw:
Suppose the motion of a spring-mass system is described by the following differential equation

:<math>
2u'' + 2\gamma u' + 18u = 0, \quad u(0) = 1,\quad u'(0) = -\frac{11}2
</math>

'''(a)''' Find all values of the parameter <math>\gamma</math> for which the system is overdamped or critically damped (that is the mass cannot pass its equilibrium position more than once, so there are no oscillatory solutions).
